Graph theory

Speaker notes go here.

title: Network Centrality and Resilience to Flood Disasters
Network Centrality and Resilience to Flood Disasters
text:
Research questions

Analysis based on graph theory, where roads are modeled as vertices and edges.

How does road connectivity change after being impacted by flooding based on connectivity metrics?
Which healthcare facilities will be most affected by flooding based on accessibility metrics?
Where are the most critical infrastructures located for accessing health facilities to reinforce urban resilience against flooding?

title: Network Centrality and Resilience to Flood Disasters
Network Centrality and Resilience to Flood Disasters
Network Centrality and Resilience to Flood Disasters
text:
Edge Betweenness




Significance of the road counting shortest paths
\[
c_{B}(v) = \sum_{\substack{s \neq t \neq v \\ s,t \in V}} \frac{\sigma(s,t|v)}{\sigma(s,t)}
\]

title: Network Centrality and Resilience to Flood Disasters
text:
Closeness




How central to other vertices is a vertex
\[
\text{CN}(v) = \frac{n - 1}{\sum_{w = 1}^{n - 1} d(w, v)}
\]
